On the other hand, when we look at the correlation between manager and foot size, conditional on director (Method 2), we are effectively separating out the different levels of director, which should reduce the confounding effect.

The reasoning behind this lies in the concept of conditional independence. Causal relationships between variables are often conditional, meaning they can change depending on the level of other variables. When we condition on director, we are essentially looking at the relationship between manager and foot size while keeping the director effect constant, thereby reducing the impact of confounding.

This concept is also supported by Pearl's back-door criterion, which is a method for identifying the casual relationships between two endogenous variables when adjusting for a set of confounders. Conditioning on director can be seen as implementing this criterion, thus helping to eliminate the confounding effect.

Conditional on director, manager and foot size are no longer directly connected to a common cause, which implies that the correlation between manager and foot size in this case may be more direct than in general. = 1 - 0.4599

= 0.5401

Since 0.4599 < 0.5401, high salary is less likely than low salary overall.
